EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
This document comprises the Five Year Update for the Federal Risk Management Plan (Federal RMP Plan)
and the California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan (CalARP RMP) for Water
Reclamation Plant No. 4 located at 63-002 Fillmore Road in Thermal, California 92254 (hereinafter referred to
as WRP No. 4 or the Plant). The Plant is owned and operated by the Coachella Valley Water District (with a
mailing address of P.O. Box 1058; Coachella, California 92236). The District's initial submittal for WRP No. 4
was made to USEPA and to the Riverside County Department of Environmental Health on June 21, 1999.
The purpose of this document is to comply with the risk management planning requirements as set forth in the
Code of Federal Regulations, Title 40, Part 68 (also known as the Federal Risk Management Plan Regulations)
and the California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5, Article 3, Section 2745.3 (also known
as the California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan - CalARP RMP Regulations).
The scope of the Federal RMP and CalARP RMP includes all operations conducted at the subject facility that
involve the storage, handling and/or use of chlorine and sulfur dioxide (i.e., chlorine and sulfur dioxide are the
only regulated substance handled at the Plant).
Policy Statement
It is the Policy of the Coachella Valley Water District (District) to conduct ALL District activities safely to prevent
Job related accidents, illnesses, and injuries to employees and others and damage to District and Others'
property. A well organized safety program provides a safe working environment and promotes increased
efficiency at ALL levels (IIPP).
ES 1.0 DESCRIPTION OF STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The primary operation conducted at WRP No. 4 is the treatment of wastewater (NAICS Code 22132 - Sewage
Treatment Facilities).
Water Reclamation Plant No. 4 is a wastewater treatment plant that treats

domestic wastes. WRP No. 4 uses
chlorine to disinfect secondary effluent and in turn uses sulfur dioxide to remove chlorine residue before the
treated effluent is discharged into receiving waters. The Plant is manned on the day shift and the process is
monitored 24-hours per day, 7-days per week, 365-days per year at the District Headquarters located in
Coachella.
Maximum Inventory of Regulated Substances
The District's Maximum Inventory of Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide is 24,000-pounds of chlorine (twelve one ton
containers, two 8 on line and four in storage) and 12,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide (six one-ton containers of
sulfur dioxide, two online and four in storage).
Site Security
In order to ensure the security of the site, the District has erected a chain link fence around the entire site.
Additionally, the entry doors to the chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage and use areas are equipped with an
intrusion security system. These site security provisions are intended to prevent unauthorized access to areas
of the Plant where chlorine and sulfur dioxide are stored, handled or used and seek to provide an added level of
safety for the storage of chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the Plant.
2.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE SCENARIOS
The Federal RMP regulations and the CalARP RMP regulations require that at least two types of release
scenarios be evaluated for their potential to impact off-site populations:
the Worst Case Release; and an Alternative Release (an accident scenario that is more credible than the worstcase
release scenario).
A number of hypothetical accidental release scenarios were postulated and evaluated for the Five Year Federal
RMP/CalARP RMP Update. These scenarios were categorized into worst-case release scenarios and
alternative release scenarios. Each of these categories of hypothetical accidental release scenarios is
discussed below.
CHLORINE AND SULFUR DIOXIDE
The storage, handling and use systems for chlorine and sulfur dioxide at the Plant are identical an

d therefore
the worst-case accidental release scenarios and the alternative release scenarios for each of these regulated
substances is identical. Each of these is discussed below:                                                                                                      Worst-Case Release Scenarios for Chlorine
In this scenario, one of the one-ton containers of chlorine on site experiences a catastrophic failure due to an
unknown event. This scenario could be initiated by an external event (i.e., an airplane, missile or meteorite
impacting the chlorine storage room or building where the one ton containers are located). It is highly
improbable that this scenario would be initiated by a seismic event. However, the possibility of this scenario
being initiated by a seismic event cannot be completely discarded. This scenario is considered to be extremely
unlikely. In the extremely unlikely case that this scenario occurs, up to 2,000-pounds of chlorine could be
released (in the worst-case). The release of chlorine could occur outdoors or indoors. Since the release can
occur out-doors (i.e., outside of the chlorine storage room during a delivery for example) the enclosure provided
by the chlorine storage room was not taken into account in evaluating the off-site consequences. Rather, it was
assumed that the chlorine released during the catastrophic accident was released outdoors forming a cloud of
chlorine vapor. The resulting vapor cloud was assumed to freely migrate off-site. Utilizing the methodology
specified by USEPA, the estimated vulnerable zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is
approximately 3.0-miles.
Alternative Release Scenarios for Chlorine
Alternative release scenarios which are considered to be more likely to occur are those which may result in the
release of anywhere from less than one-pound to up to 2000-pounds of chlorine. These scenarios include
situations such as delivery of a leaking one-ton container of chlorine to the Pla

nt, a pinhole leak in the chlorine
transfer piping or pigtails, a partial or complete failure of the chlorine transfer lines (100-percent vapor) at
various points in the system (in-doors), or the rupture or separation of the flexible connections from the online
one-ton containers to the manifold system (in-doors). In order to be conservative in the estimation of the
vulnerable zone, it was assumed that 1447-pounds of chlorine was released (over a 60-minute period) during an
accident involving the complete rupture of the flexible connection from a one-ton container to the manifold
system. It was assumed that the resulting release activates the chlorine detectors which in turn activate the
building ventilation fans. As such the chlorine released indoors, is quickly vented to the atmosphere and the
resulting cloud of chlorine vapor is free to migrate off-site. The resulting cloud of chlorine vapor was assumed to
freely migrate off-site. Utilizing the methodology specified by USEPA, the estimated vulnerable zone for this
hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 0.2-miles.
Worst-Case Release Scenarios for Sulfur Dioxide
In this scenario, one of the one-ton containers of sulfur dioxide on site experiences a catastrophic failure due to
an unknown event. This scenario could be initiated by an external event (i.e., an airplane, missile or meteorite
impacting the sulfur dioxide storage room or building where the one ton containers are located). It is highly
improbable that this scenario would be initiated by a seismic event. However, the possibility of this scenario
being initiated by a seismic event cannot be completely discarded. This scenario is considered to be extremely
unlikely. In the extremely unlikely case that this scenario occurs, up to 2,000-pounds of sulfur dioxide could be
released (in the worst-case). The release of sulfur dioxide could occur outdoors or indoors. Since the release
can occur out-doors (i.e., outside of the sulfur dioxide storage

room during a deli
very for example) the enclosure provided by the sulfur dioxide storage room was not taken into account in
evaluating the off-site consequences. Rather, it was assumed that the sulfur dioxide released during the
catastrophic accident was released outdoors forming a cloud of sulfur dioxide vapor. The resulting vapor cloud
was assumed to freely migrate off-site. Utilizing the methodology specified by USEPA, the estimated vulnerable
zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 3.1-miles.
Alternative Release Scenarios for Sulfur Dioxide
Alternative release scenarios which are considered to be more likely to occur are those which may result in the
release of anywhere from less than one-pound to up to 2000-pounds of sulfur dioxide. These scenarios include
situations such as delivery of a leaking one-ton container of sulfur dioxide to the Plant, a pinhole leak in the
sulfur dioxide transfer piping or pigtails, a partial or complete failure of the sulfur dioxide transfer lines (100-
percent vapor) at various points in the system (in-doors), or the rupture or separation of the flexible connections
from the online one-ton containers to the manifold system (in-doors). In order to be conservative in the
estimation of the vulnerable zone, it was assumed that 1347-pounds of sulfur dioxide was released (over a 60-
minute period) during an accident involving the complete rupture of the flexible connection from a one-ton
container to the manifold system (i.e., a release rate of 22.45-pounds of sulfur dioxide per minute). It was
assumed that the resulting release activates the sulfur dioxide detectors which in turn activate the building
ventilation fans. As such the sulfur dioxide released indoors, is quickly vented to the atmosphere and the
resulting cloud of sulfur dioxide vapor is free to migrate off-site. The resulting cloud of sulfur dioxide vapor was
assumed to freely migrate off-site. Utilizing the methodology specified by USEPA, t

he estimated
vulnerable zone for this hypothetical accidental release scenario is approximately 0.2-miles.
ES 3.0 FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
During the five years preceding the submittal of the Five Year Federal RMP/CalARP RMP Update, the Plant has
NOT had any accidental releases of either chlorine or sulfur dioxide that have resulted in:
Onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage; or
Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.
ES 4.0 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION
STEPS/DEVICES
The Accidental Release Prevention Program at the Plant consists of a series of programs, procedures and
policies designed to minimize the risk of accidental releases involving chlorine or sulfur dioxide. These
programs include design and operating controls such as compliance with specified codes, the District's health
and safety program, numerous standard operating procedures, the equipment inspection and maintenance
program (including a mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance program), the management of change
program, pre-start-up review, fire protection and hot work permit programs, management of- and safety ofcontractors,
accident/incident investigation procedures, emergency response plan, the Federal RMP/CalARP
RMP/OSHA PSM Program compliance auditing program, the Federal RMP/CalARP RMP/OSHA PSM Program
record keeping program and a variety of personnel training programs. Details of each of these components of
the Plant's Accidental Release Prevention Program are provided in the document entitled Federal Risk
Management Plan (Federal RMP), California Accidental Release Prevention Program Risk Management Plan
(CalARP RMP), OSHA Process Safety Management (OSHA PSM) Program, Volume I - Prevention Program.
It is highly unlikely that the Worst Case Release Scenario or Alternative Release Scenarios will occur at the
plant for the following reasons:
Both the chlorine and

sulfur dioxide processes and process areas are inspected daily;
The chlorine and sulfur dioxide containers and storage rooms are monitored 24-hours per day, 7-days per
week, 365-days per year for process leaks via automatic leak detectors;
The leak detectors are considered critical equipment and thus are incorporated into the Mechanical Integrity
Program. As such, each detector is well maintained and tested twice each month;
ALL chlorine and sulfur dioxide storage, handling and use area entry doors are equipped with intruder alarms to
guard against unauthorized entry and/or vandalism;
The flexible connections are replaced annually per manufacturer's specifications to minimize the possibility of
leaks/releases due to corrosion;
ALL one-ton containers stored/managed onsite are secured in-place via two chain binders to prevent movement
or dislodging due to seismic events; and
ALL Plant Operators and Members of the Emergency Response Team are trained to respond to- and stopprocess
leaks.
There are a number of detection and monitoring devices and alarms designed to ensure the continued safe
operation of Water Reclamation Plant No. 4. These devices are located throughout the Plant and monitor
various aspects of Plant Operations.
Alarms
WRP No. 4 is equipped with Leak Detectors that are designed to detect chlorine in the chlorine storage and use
area at or above 1-ppm and sulfur dioxide in the sulfur dioxide storage and use area at or above 2-ppm. When
one of the chlorine detectors senses a gas leak at or above 1-ppm, a visual and audible alarm on the
annunciator panel will activate and an alarm is transmitted to District Control at Headquarters. At 3-ppm of
chlorine the beacon lights on top of the affected building will come on and the ventilation fan in the affected
room will start to evacuate the room of excess gas. These alarms can only be reset and cleared after the leak
detectors sense less than 1-ppm of gas. The alarms are tested by District Operators twice each mon

th.
Additionally, the District's Communications Shop inspects, tests and calibrates the chlorine alarm system on a
monthly schedule. The set-points for the sulfur dioxide leak detectors are 2-ppm and 5-ppm. ALL other aspects
of the sulfur dioxide leak detector's and alarm system are identical to those of the chlorine leak detectors and
alarm system.
ES 5.0 EMERGENCY RESPONSE
The Coachella Valley Water District recognizes that emergency planning and emergency response are an
integral component of risk management. As such, the District, as part of its hazardous materials business plan
(HMBP) and Emergency Response Program for Water Reclamation Plant No. 4, has developed and
implemented an emergency response plan and an emergency evacuation plan.
Call Outs
When a gas leak alarm occurs during the hours that a Plant is staffed, the Plant Operators will respond to the
leak with three operators. The Chlorine Response Team can be dispatched to the Plant during the staffed hours
if the Plant Staff are unable to respond to the leak with a three person crew.
When control receives a gas leak alarm after hours, the Control Operator will call out the Chlorine Response
Team and the Sanitation Standby Operator. Upon arrival at the scene, both will wait at the entrance gate for the
other to arrive and will enter the Plant together.
Response Teams
Emergency response and any work with chlorine or sulfur dioxide connections requires a minimum of three
employees to be present. ALL Plant Operators are trained in Emergency Response. The crew of employees
trained in response to chlorine leaks at the District's domestic well sites have been trained to respond to
chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide leaks at WRP No. 4 as well. After hours this two-person crew responds with the
standby operator to unmanned Plants or to other Plants that may need assistance. There are always three
employees on call with pagers ready to respond to chlorine emergencies.
The on call crew is rotated weekly.
Training
Chl

orine response personnel are scheduled to be trained quarterly in the use of emergency repair kits, the use
of personal protective equipment (PPE), and District Emergency Response Procedures. Furthermore, chlorine
emergency response personnel are trained annually in the safe storage and handling of chlorine and sulfur
dioxide and in CPR/First Aid. The District also has a "cut-out" one-ton container and a 150-pound cylinder that
are used to simulate emergency releases and to practice emergency response/repairs and supply isolation
procedures.
Response to Minor Leaks
Two employees will respond with Self-Contained Breathing Apparatuses (SCBAs), Chlorine "B" Repair Kits,
gloves and a bottle of 26 Baume Ammonia. The third crew member will also respond with an SCBA and stay
near the truck radio.
The first and second person will don their SCBAs, keeping each other in sight at all times. Using the ammonia,
they will locate the chlorine leak. Once the leak is located and confirmed to be a system leak and not a vessel
tank, the gas supply valve on the container can be shut off by turning the valve clockwise one full turn. When
this has been done, the Third Crew Member will let Control know whether repairs have been made or if further
assistance is needed.
Response to Major Leaks
The District's response to Major Leaks is similar to its response for Minor Leaks, except that the Response
Team will wear fully encapsulated suits if a severe gas leak has occurred or if the Response Team finds a
vessel/tank leak. The Third Crew Member will notify Control to send Police and Fire Department Personnel to
the scene to secure and evacuate the surrounding area, as necessary. The District's standby personnel and
Training/Safety Specialist will be called as well.
ES 6.0 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
A detailed hazard and operability study (i.e., hazards analysis) was performed on ALL operations involving
chlorine and sulfur
dioxide in order to evaluate the potential for accidental relea

ses in June 12, 2009. As a result of the process
hazards analysis update performed a number of recommendations were made to improve the safety of the
operations conducted at the Plant. The District is currently evaluating the recommended actions and also
evaluating implementation options.
ES 7.0 FOR MORE INFORMATION
The Coachella Valley Water District recognizes that some persons may be interested in obtaining more detailed
information regarding the Five Year Federal RMP and CalARP RMP Update and various Prevention Program
components not discussed herein. Interested parties that have additional questions regarding the Risk
Management Plan for Water Reclamation Plant No. 4 and or the Chlorine or Sulfur Dioxide Prevention
